cards.summary: Fiber state corruption occurs on x86_64 Linux when `Workflow.timeout` expires and is immediately followed by `Workflow.execute_activity`, causing a NoMethodError where `Fiber.yield` returns true instead of a Resolution object. The issue does not occur on aarch64 architecture and can be worked around by calling `Workflow.sleep(0)` before the activity.
cards.userImpact: Workflows on x86_64 Linux that use `Workflow.timeout` followed by `Workflow.execute_activity` crash when the timeout expires, blocking long-running patterns like opportunity nurturing workflows.
cards.rootCause: When a timeout expires on x86_64, the wait condition fiber is not properly cleaned up when an exception is raised from yield. This leaves the wait condition fiber registered while the execute activity is currently yielded, causing the resolution to be sent to the wrong fiber context, resulting in true being returned instead of a Resolution object.
cards.workaround: Add `Workflow.sleep(0)` before `Workflow.execute_activity` to force a clean fiber yield/resume cycle after timeout expiration.
cards.resolutionDetails: SDK maintainers identified the root cause as improper cleanup of wait condition fibers on timeout, leading to fiber resolution routing issues. The issue was architecture-specific due to timing/memory layout differences between x86_64 and aarch64.
cards.keyQuote: when the wait timeout occurs, that wait condition is left around... we are not properly removing the wait condition when an exception is raised from yield (which is what timeout does)

cards.proposedFix: Implement support for new server APIs (referenced in temporalio/api#640) to allow clients to start activities and workers to execute activities outside workflow context.
cards.keyQuote: Allow executing activities without a workflow. The clients must support the new (upcoming) server APIs for starting, managing and getting results of activities.

cards.summary: User cannot test Temporal Ruby workflows that use `wait_condition` with signals in the time-skipping test environment. The signal is received correctly (verified via query), but the workflow doesn't resume execution after the signal, causing timeouts when trying to get the result.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot effectively test signal-driven workflows in the Ruby SDK's time-skipping environment, forcing them to use real Temporal servers or alternative testing approaches.
cards.rootCause: Time-skipping doesn't automatically progress workflows until `workflow_handle.result` is called; manual `sleep` on the environment is required to advance time after signals, but this behavior may not be clearly documented or intuitive.
cards.proposedFix: Clarify documentation on time-skipping behavior with signals, or improve automatic time progression when signals are processed in test environments.
cards.workaround: Call `sleep` on the environment to manually advance time after sending a signal; run `execute_workflow` in a background thread for automatic progression.
cards.keyQuote: the automatic time-skipping doesn't kick in until you wait for the workflow result. So the workflow does not progress automatically until you wait for the result

cards.summary: OpenTelemetry instrumentation in workflows can become non-deterministic when libraries monkey-patch Context.current, causing issues even though the durable scheduler is supposed to be disabled. The fix is to disable the durable scheduler for all OTel calls, not just the obvious non-deterministic ones.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using OpenTelemetry instrumentation may become non-deterministic due to third-party library monkey-patching, causing workflow replay failures and unpredictable behavior.
cards.rootCause: Some OpenTelemetry libraries (e.g., DataDog) monkey-patch Context.current, making it non-deterministic even though the durable scheduler is disabled for obvious OTel calls.
cards.proposedFix: Disable the durable scheduler for every OpenTelemetry call in the workflow interceptor, not just the obvious non-deterministic ones.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by ensuring all OTel calls in the workflow interceptor run with the durable scheduler disabled to prevent any monkey-patched Context.current calls from affecting workflow determinism.
cards.keyQuote: we just need to disable the durable scheduler for every OTel call, not just the obvious non-deterministic ones

cards.summary: ActiveModel classes fail in workflows because they use ConcurrentMap internally, which relies on Thread::Mutex that is forbidden in workflows. The issue occurs when accessing attributes or using models with ActiveModel::Attributes, causing NondeterminismError.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use ActiveModel classes (a common Rails library) in Temporal workflows, limiting framework compatibility and forcing workarounds or alternative data structures.
cards.rootCause: ActiveModel uses concurrent-ruby's ConcurrentMap which employs Thread::Mutex for thread-safe operations. Workflows cannot use synchronization primitives because they need to be deterministic and replayed safely.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a WorkflowSafeObject mixin that wraps calls with Workflow::Unsafe::durable_scheduler_disabled to allow safe execution of normally-forbidden constructs in workflows.
cards.keyQuote: ConcurrentMap use is so pervasive in ActiveModel, it is unreasonable for us to ask users not to use anything relying on it.

cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently configure worker heartbeat intervals in the Ruby SDK, limiting their ability to tune worker connection stability.

cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to enable worker heartbeating configuration in the Ruby SDK
cards.keyQuote: Worker heartbeating is implemented in Core, need to enable worker heartbeating by allowing users to specify the worker heartbeat interval when initializing Core Runtime

cards.summary: Retry policy's non_retryable_error_types parameter doesn't match exceptions with module/namespace qualifiers (e.g., ActiveRecord::RecordNotFound). The SDK strips namespaces when converting errors to ApplicationError, causing activities to retry when they should fail instantly.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use fully-qualified error type names in non_retryable_error_types, forcing them to use unqualified names or implement custom workarounds, which causes unexpected retries during migration from other SDKs.
cards.rootCause: By design, the SDK converts exceptions to ApplicationError with only the unqualified error type name (without namespace), so retry policy matching against qualified names fails.
cards.workaround: Implement a custom failure converter or activity interceptor to preserve the full error class name when creating ApplicationError, as demonstrated in the issue comments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Determined to be intentional design by SDK maintainer. The unqualified error type name is by-design and consistent across SDKs. Users should use custom failure converters or interceptors to preserve qualified names if needed.
cards.keyQuote: By default, exceptions raised from activity are converted to ApplicationError with the type as the unqualified error type name. This is the same in all SDKs.

cards.summary: Ruby SDK needs to ensure fibers and workflow instances are properly garbage collected when workflows are evicted. Initial investigation suggested fibers held by threads need explicit cleanup, but recent analysis indicates suspended fibers can be GC'd naturally if all references are removed, though deterministic testing has proven difficult.
cards.userImpact: Potential memory leaks from uncollected fibers on workflow eviction could cause high memory usage in long-running Ruby Temporal applications.
cards.rootCause: Initial assumption that threads hold strong references to suspended fibers preventing GC has been reconsidered; actual mechanism and test verification remains unclear.
cards.proposedFix: Consider implementation approach similar to Python SDK PR #499 where exceptions are raised in suspended fibers to force completion without side effects, or develop deterministic GC verification tests.
cards.keyQuote: We do not believe there is a memory leak, but we struggle to write a deterministic test for this.

cards.summary: Users should be able to require the payload codec from the data converter file in the Ruby SDK. Currently, the payload codec is not exported when requiring 'temporalio/converters', making it unavailable despite being part of the data converter functionality.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access the payload codec through the standard converters require path, requiring them to know about alternative import methods.
cards.rootCause: The payload codec is not exported from the data converter file which is required from the top-level converters file.
cards.proposedFix: Export the payload codec from the data converter file so it is available when requiring 'temporalio/converters'.
cards.keyQuote: Users should be able to `require 'temporalio/converters'` and have payload codec, but it is not required from the data converter file

cards.summary: After upgrading to v0.6.0, Ruby SDK workflows deadlock with a 2-second timeout error due to call tracing overhead. The illegal call tracer was causing excessive validation that made workflows slow enough to trigger the deadlock detector.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to v0.6.0 experience consistent workflow deadlocks with 2-second timeout errors, preventing benchmarks and other async workflows from completing.
cards.rootCause: The illegal call tracer introduced in v0.6.0 added significant overhead to validation, causing workflows to exceed the 2-second deadlock detection threshold.
cards.proposedFix: PR #332 reduces the scope of the illegal call tracer validation to minimize performance impact and prevent workflows from hitting the deadlock detector.
cards.workaround: Set `debug_mode: true` when creating the worker to disable the deadlock detector, allowing CPU-bound work to take longer than 2 seconds.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #332 which reduced call tracing scope to prevent performance degradation that triggered deadlock detection.
cards.keyQuote: This is a case where, with the illegal call tracer on, it actually does take over 2s to process things. There is also a bug preventing the disabling of the call tracer we will fix.

cards.userImpact: Users need gRPC binary metadata header support to ensure compatibility with Temporal services and cross-language communication patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Require ASCII-based string values for `-bin` keys and set those as Tonic metadata binary values

cards.resolutionDetails: This is a feature request that was tracked and likely implemented to align Ruby SDK observability with other SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: See issue description here: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-python/issues/1041

cards.summary: Improve Ruby scheduler memory efficiency by replacing array-based ready fiber list with a proper queue data structure to avoid repeated shift/append operations.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience unnecessary memory pressure and garbage collection overhead due to inefficient array operations in the fiber scheduler.
cards.rootCause: Using array with repeated shift and append operations creates unnecessary memory churn instead of using a proper queue data structure.
cards.proposedFix: Replace array-based ready fiber list with a queue data structure using non-blocking pop operations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Author noted that while queue would be cleaner, the current implementation completely drains the array anyway, making the optimization not beneficial in practice.
cards.keyQuote: Note, queue is a bit blocked on how it is used with our fiber scheduler. The way we completely drain this array means it's actually not a big deal here.

cards.summary: Implement client-side trimming of failure proto to reduce server-side truncation and wrapping. The server currently truncates oversized failures and wraps them in error responses; this feature explores doing size limiting on the client before sending to prevent this behavior, with opt-out support for custom server limits.
cards.userImpact: Users experiencing truncated failure information due to server-side size limits could preserve complete failure details through client-side trimming.
cards.rootCause: Server-side failure proto size limits cause truncation and wrapping of failures in error responses.
cards.proposedFix: Implement client-side trimming of failure proto before sending to server, with configurable opt-out for users with custom server-side limits.
cards.keyQuote: if failure proto is too large server side, they truncate it _and_ wrap in server error. See if there's something we can do client side before the failure is sent

cards.summary: ScopedLogger fails when comparing log levels against non-integer values like symbols. This occurs when using libraries like semantic_logger that return symbols for Logger#level instead of integers, causing a type comparison error during workflow execution.
cards.userImpact: Workflows fail with type comparison errors when running in Rails applications using semantic_logger instead of the standard Logger.
cards.rootCause: ScopedLogger performs integer comparison on Logger#level, but semantic_logger returns symbols instead of integers, causing 'comparison of Integer with :debug failed' error.
cards.proposedFix: Update ScopedLogger to handle both integer and symbol log levels, converting symbols to their integer equivalents for comparison.
cards.keyQuote: When I inspect those values, severity is 2, Logger::Unknown is undefined (should be Logger::UNKNOWN?), and level is :debug.

cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented as part of cross-SDK enhancement effort
cards.keyQuote: Add first execution run ID to workflow info

cards.summary: Feature request to disallow Ruby stdlib synchronization constructs (sleep, Mutex, ConditionVariable, Queue) in workflows before GA. These constructs are fiber-aware and implicitly made durable, but can cause issues when third-party libraries use them unexpectedly, leading to hung workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users may inadvertently use stdlib synchronization constructs in workflows through third-party libraries, causing workflows to hang when durable locks are not properly released.
cards.rootCause: Stdlib synchronization constructs are fiber-aware and implicitly made durable by the Ruby SDK, but third-party libraries (like loggers) may use mutexes expecting same-process semantics, creating durability mismatches.
cards.proposedFix: Implement illegal call tracing to disallow Mutex, ConditionVariable, Queue, and SizedQueue in workflows, and provide workflow-safe equivalents similar to existing sleep and timeout replacements.
cards.workaround: Wrap third-party library calls in blocks that disable the durable scheduler tracer.
cards.keyQuote: Every Google Protobuf field access uses a mutex. It may not be reasonable for us to wrap every proto access in a disable-tracer block...

cards.summary: User requests a built-in error notification mechanism for workflow failures to integrate with external error tracking services like Bugsnag. The SDK maintainer recommends using interceptors instead and points to existing samples.

cards.summary: Ruby SDK does not allow multiple workflow handlers (signal, update, query) to share the same name, unlike other SDKs. This causes a RuntimeError when attempting to define handlers with identical names for different handler types.
cards.userImpact: Ruby developers cannot implement the same handler logic for different handler types with a shared name, forcing workarounds and reducing code reusability compared to other SDKs.
cards.rootCause: The Ruby SDK's handler decorator implementation does not allow multiple handler types to share the same name, enforcing a one-name-per-handler-type constraint that other SDKs do not have.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the Ruby SDK handler registration mechanism to allow multiple handlers of different types to share the same name, matching the behavior of Python and other SDKs.
cards.workaround: Use different names for each handler type (signal, update, query) even if they implement the same business logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: The Ruby SDK was updated to allow multiple workflow handlers of different types to share the same name, bringing it into parity with other Temporal SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow signal UpdateOrder already defined as a different handler type (RuntimeError)

cards.summary: The failure converter in the Ruby SDK is not properly defaulting the error type to an unqualified class name. The issue points to a specific line in the code that needs to extract only the class name without the module namespace.
cards.userImpact: Application errors may not be properly converted and serialized when being passed through the Temporal workflow system, potentially causing errors to lose their type information.
cards.rootCause: The failure converter is not extracting the unqualified class name from the error object, likely including the full module namespace instead.
cards.proposedFix: Change the error type extraction to use `error.class.name.to_s.split('::').last` to get only the unqualified class name.
cards.resolutionDetails: The code was updated to properly extract the unqualified class name by splitting on '::' and taking the last element.
cards.keyQuote: error.class.name.to_s.split('::').last

cards.summary: Ruby SDK drops namespace from activity and workflow class names by default, causing potential naming collisions when the same class name is used in different namespaces. The issue was resolved by design decision to maintain compatibility with other SDKs and CLI/UI clarity.
cards.userImpact: Users with identically-named workflow or activity classes in different namespaces may experience unexpected name collisions unless they explicitly specify custom names.
cards.rootCause: By design, the SDK strips namespace from class names when generating workflow and activity names for SDK/CLI/UI compatibility with other language SDKs, which typically use unqualified names.
cards.workaround: Explicitly set workflow_name or activity_name using `workflow_name` or `activity_name` methods, or create base classes that automatically set the name to the fully qualified class name using the `inherited` hook.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers clarified this is by design for SDK/CLI/UI compatibility. Users should use explicit workflow_name/activity_name if they need the fully qualified name.
cards.keyQuote: Using the unqualified class name by default is by design here and in other SDKs... this default is chosen for SDK/CLI/UI compatibility/clarity.

cards.summary: Sorbet type checker is creating duplicate singleton methods on Temporal workflow definition classes, causing a RuntimeError. The issue occurs when using Sorbet runtime decorators on handler methods, and has been resolved in recent Sorbet releases.
cards.userImpact: Users employing Sorbet for type checking encounter runtime errors that prevent workflow definitions with signal handlers from loading.
cards.rootCause: Sorbet runtime adds singleton methods when decorating instance methods, conflicting with Temporal's own singleton method handling in the Definition class.
cards.proposedFix: Detect when Sorbet is adding a method and ignore it, or await fixes in Sorbet that prevent duplicate singleton method creation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved in recent Sorbet releases (sorbet/sorbet#8592 and sorbet/sorbet#9084 were fixed upstream)
cards.keyQuote: Attempting to override Temporal-defined class definition method (RuntimeError)

cards.summary: Child workflows invoked via execute_child_workflow don't display as relationships in the parent workflow or dashboard UI, despite running and completing. They only appear in the parent's execution history.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot track or monitor child workflow relationships when using execute_child_workflow with abandon parent_close_policy, breaking observability of hierarchical workflows.
cards.rootCause: Child workflows started but not fully accepted by server before parent workflow completes, causing them to become no-ops or not register as relationships.
cards.proposedFix: Wait for child workflow start requests to be accepted by server before parent completes using Future.all_of().wait() to ensure all child starts are properly registered.
cards.workaround: Add a sleep delay after invoking child workflows and before parent returns, allowing sufficient time for child workflow starts to be accepted.
cards.resolutionDetails: Solution provided in comments: use Future.all_of to wait for all child workflow start requests to complete before parent workflow finishes.
cards.keyQuote: Future doesn't have a 'started', you'd wait until the future completes which represents start completing

cards.summary: The temporalio Ruby gem fails to install from source in Docker on aarch64-linux due to Cargo manifest issues with the temporalio_bridge library. The issue occurs despite the correct platform being available, suggesting a dependency resolution problem.
cards.userImpact: Users trying to install the temporalio gem in Docker containers on aarch64-linux are blocked from using the SDK due to build failures.
cards.rootCause: Bundler is selecting the source gem instead of the aarch64-linux prebuilt gem, causing Cargo to fail when parsing the manifest because the temporalio_bridge library cannot be found in the source build.
cards.workaround: Add aarch64-linux to the PLATFORMS section in Gemfile.lock to force selection of the prebuilt gem.
cards.resolutionDetails: The gem maintainers clarified that building from source is not supported and prebuilt gems are available; the workaround of adding the platform to Gemfile.lock solved the user's issue.
cards.keyQuote: This gem does not support building from a source gem at this time... I wonder why it is getting the source gem instead of the aarch64-linux one.

cards.userImpact: Users cannot manually control pagination when listing workflows; they must either fetch all at once or use automatic enumerable traversal.
cards.rootCause: Current enumerable design doesn't expose page token handling for manual pagination control.
cards.proposedFix: Create a dedicated `list_workflow_page` method with optional page_size and next_page_token parameters, returning a ListWorkflowPage object containing items and next page token, while refactoring `list_workflows` to use this internally.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by implementing a separate paginated method approach (#285) rather than dual return types.
cards.keyQuote: Have two possible return types for `#list_workflows`, depending on whether `page_size` is `nil` or not... Define a separate method for the paginated version

cards.summary: Activity outbound heartbeat implementation incorrectly accesses the current activity context to get task token and activity info. This is problematic because heartbeat may be happening in a different thread/fiber, leading to potential race conditions or incorrect context access.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly implement heartbeating in activities that run on different threads/fibers, blocking production deployments.
cards.rootCause: The heartbeat implementation uses `current` to access activity context, but this is unsafe when heartbeat executes on a different thread/fiber than the activity itself.
cards.proposedFix: Task token should be provided through a different mechanism rather than accessing the current context during heartbeat.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed and gem artifacts were prepared for release; users could build from source or wait for official release.

cards.summary: Ruby SDK incorrectly compares workflow update stage enum as integer instead of symbol, causing ArgumentError. The comparison needs to resolve the protobuf enum value before comparison.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot start or execute workflow updates because the SDK crashes with an ArgumentError when comparing enum values.
cards.rootCause: Protobuf enums in Ruby are symbols, not integers, but the code compares them as integers using the >= operator against a numeric value.
cards.proposedFix: Use Api::Enums::V1::UpdateWorkflowExecutionLifecycleStage.resolve(resp.stage) to properly convert the enum before comparison.
cards.resolutionDetails: The enum comparison logic was updated to properly resolve protobuf enum values before numeric comparison.
cards.keyQuote: enums inside protos may be symbols instead of integers, so we were improperly comparing as if it was an integer

cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably test workflows that spawn child workflows in the Ruby SDK test environment, breaking test reliability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Reporter was unable to reproduce with a minimal example and closed the issue.
cards.keyQuote: With a child workflow, the following code has `result` nil, even if you try to wait for workflow handle. This happens often, but not all the time, implying a race condition?

cards.summary: Feature request to investigate and validate fork behavior in Ruby SDK. Core-based SDK objects cannot be used across forks, requiring documentation and validation that Temporal objects and clients are not reused post-fork, with consideration for eager runtime/client PID validation.
cards.userImpact: Users working with fork-based servers (Rails, Puma) need clear guidance on whether Temporal objects are safe to use across forks and what patterns are supported.
cards.rootCause: Core-based SDKs maintain internal state tied to specific processes, making them unsafe for cross-fork reuse without explicit process ID tracking and validation.
cards.proposedFix: Store process ID on runtime and validate on every client and worker call that they execute on the same PID as the runtime that created them, raising clear exceptions if violated.
cards.resolutionDetails: Runtime PID validation implemented to detect and prevent cross-fork usage with clear error messages.
cards.keyQuote: it is best that we store the process ID on the runtime and make sure every client call and every worker call are on the same PID as the runtime.

cards.summary: Time#iso8601 method is incorrectly flagged as an illegal call in workflows due to internal calls that access current time. The SDK needs a more sophisticated illegal call detection system that can skip checking based on call stack context, and also support Time#initialize with deterministic parameters.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use Time#iso8601 or Time#initialize with parameters in workflows, breaking datetime serialization and deserialization workflows.
cards.rootCause: The illegal call tracer cannot distinguish between user-initiated Time method calls and internal time access within those methods, causing false positives when Ruby's stdlib accesses current time internally.
cards.proposedFix: Implement an abstract 'check illegal' class that allows workflow-stateful stack-aware checking to skip validation further down the call stack. Support Time#initialize detection with parameter inspection via TracePoint binding.
cards.resolutionDetails: Enhanced illegal call detection with stack-aware skipping and parameter inspection for deterministic Time method calls.
cards.keyQuote: We need to find some way to exclude this... Put it behind a very generic 'check illegal' abstract class so others can have implementations.

cards.summary: Add support for payload conversion hints in the Ruby SDK, allowing developers to specify type information for deserialization of activity/workflow inputs and outputs, signals, queries, and updates.
cards.userImpact: Developers can provide type hints to improve payload deserialization accuracy for activities, workflows, signals, queries, and updates.
cards.proposedFix: Add hint methods to activities/workflows, add input_hints/output_hint to signals/queries/updates, add hint/hints parameters to PayloadConverter and DataConverter methods, and explore other deserialization contexts like memo and heartbeat details.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented with support for payload conversion hints via hint parameters and definition methods, with decision to defer native Struct/Data type support to future work.
cards.keyQuote: Add `activity_input_hint`, `activity_output_hint`, `workflow_input_hint`, and `workflow_output_hint` definition methods to activities/workflows

cards.summary: Create a high-level client for Ruby SDK to manage worker deployments and control plane operations, following patterns established in the Go SDK implementation.
cards.userImpact: Ruby SDK users need a high-level client API to manage worker deployments and versioning, currently unavailable in the Ruby implementation.
cards.proposedFix: Implement worker versioning high-level client for Ruby SDK, modeling it after the Go SDK implementation.
cards.keyQuote: Create the high-level client for control plane operations concerning worker deployments. See the Go one as an example

cards.summary: Intermittent test failure in test_metric_basics where expected metric count of 1 was receiving 2 instead. Root cause identified as OpenTelemetry metrics issue with incorrect attributes in Prometheus output.
cards.userImpact: Tests occasionally fail intermittently in CI, reducing confidence in test suite reliability and blocking deployments.
cards.rootCause: OpenTelemetry was putting strange metrics in Prometheus with incorrect attributes compared to what was recorded
cards.workaround: Commenting out the problematic metric validation temporarily until OpenTelemetry upgrade
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved after Core upgrade; has not recurred since the upgrade
cards.keyQuote: There is something strange with OTel where it is putting some strange metrics up in Prometheus that don't have the attributes right as we recorded.

cards.summary: Rails lazy loading during development and testing causes IO errors in workflows because activity classes are lazily loaded, violating Temporal's no-IO-in-workflow constraint. Documentation is needed to clarify how to configure Rails to handle this safely, similar to existing Single-Table Inheritance guidance.
cards.userImpact: Rails developers cannot easily test workflows during development/testing due to IO errors from lazy-loaded activity classes.
cards.rootCause: Rails lazy loading by default during dev/test triggers activity class loading via bootsnap/zeitwerk, which performs file IO that violates Temporal's no-IO-in-workflow constraint.
cards.proposedFix: Add documentation similar to Rails STI guide explaining how to configure eager loading or use Unsafe.illegal_call_tracing_disabled for Rails activity loading.
cards.workaround: Can wrap lazy-loaded code in Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.illegal_call_tracing_disabled block to suppress IO restrictions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation added to clarify Rails lazy loading configuration for workflow testing.
cards.keyQuote: Cannot access File path from inside a workflow. If this is known to be safe, the code can be run in a Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.illegal_call_tracing_disabled block.

cards.summary: Test flake in test_queue where first workflow can complete before the second starts, causing assertion failures on workflow IDs. Issue appears resolved after Core upgrade but may recur.
cards.userImpact: Causes intermittent CI test failures that block development workflows.
cards.rootCause: Sticky worker unavailability causing race condition where first workflow completes before second workflow starts, leading to unexpected workflow ID reuse.
cards.proposedFix: Add failed-only ID reuse policy to the last execute_workflow call in the test.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue not reproduced after Temporal Core upgrade; closed pending reoccurrence.
cards.keyQuote: sticky worker unavailable, please use original task queue.

cards.summary: Feature request to use exception full messages (including stack traces) in workflow and activity task failure logs instead of just logging the exception object. This would improve debugging visibility.
cards.userImpact: Users would have better visibility into workflow and activity failures through more detailed log messages including stack traces.
cards.proposedFix: Use the full_message field when logging exceptions for activities and workflow task failures to include stack trace information.
cards.resolutionDetails: After review, determined that the SDK is already logging the full activity and workflow task failure by sending the exception as a separate log statement which shows the stack trace.
cards.keyQuote: After review, it looks like we are logging the full activity and workflow task failure by sending the exception as a separate log statement which seems to show the stack trace.

cards.summary: The `auto_time_skipping_disabled` method in the Ruby SDK test framework incorrectly disables auto time skipping after exiting the block, causing tests to timeout when attempting to resume normal time progression after the block completes.
cards.userImpact: Tests that need to temporarily disable auto time skipping timeout and fail, blocking users from writing comprehensive workflow tests.
cards.rootCause: The `already_disabled` variable initialization in `auto_time_skipping_disabled` is not properly negated, causing the time skipping state to not be correctly restored after the block exits.
cards.proposedFix: Negate the `already_disabled` variable initialization in the `auto_time_skipping_disabled` method.
cards.resolutionDetails: PR was accepted and merged with the fix to properly handle the already_disabled flag negation.
cards.keyQuote: I believe the initialization of `already_disabled` in `auto_time_skipping_disabled` is the problem. Just need to negate it.

cards.summary: Workflow info start time in Ruby SDK should reflect the workflow's actual start time, not the first task's start time. This is a breaking change opportunity for Ruby since it hasn't reached GA yet.
cards.userImpact: Users get incorrect workflow start time information, which could cause logic errors in time-based decisions or monitoring.
cards.rootCause: Workflow info start time is incorrectly set to first task start time instead of workflow start time
cards.proposedFix: Change workflow info start time to use the workflow's actual start time
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by updating workflow info start time to reflect workflow start time instead of first task start time
cards.keyQuote: Change the workflow info start time to be the workflow's start time. In Python and .NET we have backwards compatibility constraints

cards.summary: Ruby SDK needs support for activity reset functionality, similar to what's available in other Temporal SDKs. This feature is partially implemented in PR #283 but requires a released dev server and test confirmation before being marked complete.
cards.userImpact: Ruby SDK users cannot reset activities during testing and development, limiting testing capabilities compared to other Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement activity reset functionality in the Ruby SDK, with implementation partially done in PR #283
cards.resolutionDetails: Partially implemented in PR #283; awaiting released dev server with functionality and test confirmation
cards.keyQuote: Half of this is done in #283, but not marking this complete until we can have a test confirming behavior

cards.summary: Unregistered local activities should cause workflow task failure in Ruby SDK. This is a bug where the SDK is not properly validating and failing when an unregistered local activity is invoked.
cards.userImpact: Users can unknowingly execute unregistered local activities without getting proper failure feedback, leading to silent errors and incorrect workflow behavior.
cards.rootCause: Ruby SDK is not validating that local activities are registered before execution and failing the workflow task when they are not.
cards.resolutionDetails: Workflow task now properly fails when attempting to execute an unregistered local activity.
cards.keyQuote: Unregistered Local Activity should fail Workflow Task

cards.summary: OpenTelemetry integration is using incorrect timestamp conversion to nanoseconds, causing failures with OTLP. The fix requires using Time objects directly from Temporalio::Workflow.now instead of converting to nanos.
cards.userImpact: OpenTelemetry integration fails when exporting traces via OTLP due to incorrect timestamp handling.
cards.rootCause: Timestamp values are being converted to nanoseconds when they should remain as Time objects from Temporalio::Workflow.now
cards.proposedFix: Change lines 458-464 in temporalio/lib/temporalio/contrib/open_telemetry.rb to use Time objects directly without nanos conversion
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by updating the OpenTelemetry timestamp handling to use Time objects directly instead of converting to nanoseconds
cards.keyQuote: need to change to just use the `Time` from `Temporalio::Workflow.now` as the timestamp, do not convert to nanos

cards.summary: Add a way to disable implicit durable timers in Ruby SDK workflows, particularly for use with OpenTelemetry simple span processors that need non-durable timeouts. Implementation requires `Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.implicit_durable_timers_disabled` helper and integration with OTel span creation.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently use OpenTelemetry simple span processors in workflows because the implicit durable timeouts conflict with non-durable timeout requirements.
cards.rootCause: Implicit durable timers are always enabled by default, but some telemetry use cases (simple span processors) require non-durable timeouts which are incompatible.
cards.proposedFix: Create `Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.implicit_durable_timers_disabled` helper to allow disabling implicit durable timers, and integrate with OTel span creation/recording.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented to allow disabling implicit durable timers for compatibility with OpenTelemetry simple span processors.
cards.keyQuote: we need `Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.implicit_durable_timers_disabled` helper

cards.summary: Feature request to warn when the server-provided task start time differs significantly from when the SDK begins processing the task. Request was declined as too niche.
cards.userImpact: Users would receive warnings when task timing discrepancies occur, helping identify timing-related issues during task execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Declined by maintainers as the feature was deemed too niche for the use cases it would serve.
cards.keyQuote: We're not gonna do this. Too niche.

cards.summary: Feature request to display the retry policy on activity information in the Ruby SDK, referenced from a cross-SDK features issue.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily inspect the retry policy configuration for activities at runtime, requiring them to reference code or configuration files.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented to show retry policy on activity info, consistent with cross-SDK feature request
cards.keyQuote: Show retry policy on activity info

cards.summary: Feature request to evaluate explicit Rails integration/gem for the Ruby SDK, including Rails config/DI, code generation, ActiveJob integration, and ActiveModel/ActiveRecord support. After research and sample development, the team concluded there isn't enough substantial Rails-specific integration needed to justify an explicit gem beyond documentation and samples.
cards.userImpact: Ruby developers using Rails can follow the sample implementation and documentation for Temporal integration without requiring an explicit SDK gem.
cards.proposedFix: Provide sample Rails application and documentation on using Temporal with Rails, focusing on ActiveModel/ActiveRecord conversion support.
cards.workaround: Use plain Ruby SDK without Rails-specific integration; manual client initialization and setup.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team determined that insufficient Rails-specific integration points exist to justify an explicit gem. A sample implementation at https://github.com/temporalio/samples-ruby/tree/main/rails_app was created to demonstrate integration without requiring SDK-level support.
cards.keyQuote: Rails integration has been demonstrated in a sample at https://github.com/temporalio/samples-ruby/tree/main/rails_app, but there is nothing substantial enough over plain Ruby use to justify an explicit integration

cards.summary: Ruby SDK needs to implement application failure logging and metrics behavior according to ApplicationErrorCategory. This requires waiting for core SDK implementation to provide the necessary foundation.
cards.userImpact: Users will have standardized logging and metrics behavior for application failures consistent with the ApplicationErrorCategory specification.
cards.proposedFix: Apply corresponding logging behavior for ApplicationErrorCategory once core SDK provides the foundation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation completed following core SDK foundation work.
cards.keyQuote: Core-based SDKs only need to apply corresponding logging behaviour, core handles metrics.

cards.summary: Activities that are paused should have their heartbeating interrupted to prevent unnecessary heartbeat signals while activities are suspended.
cards.userImpact: Users experience unnecessary heartbeat signals being sent for paused activities, wasting resources and potentially causing confusion in activity monitoring.
cards.rootCause: The heartbeating mechanism does not check or respect the pause state of activities before sending heartbeats.
cards.resolutionDetails: Heartbeating activities are now properly interrupted when activities are paused.
cards.keyQuote: Heartbeating activities should be interrupted when the activities are paused.

cards.summary: Allow io_wait-based fiber calls within a special unsafe context in the Ruby SDK. Currently blocked by a TODO, this feature would enable controlled I/O operations in workflows similar to the existing illegal_call_tracing_disabled helper.
cards.userImpact: Users who need to perform I/O operations within workflows would have a documented, controlled way to do so through an explicit unsafe context.
cards.proposedFix: Implement Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.io_enabled helper that allows io_wait fiber scheduler calls to pass through when enabled, with clear errors when used outside the context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to allow io_wait fiber calls within an unsafe context similar to illegal_call_tracing_disabled.
cards.keyQuote: Make a new `Temporalio::Workflow::Unsafe.io_enabled` helper (akin to `illegal_call_tracing_disabled`) and if in that context, allow `io_wait` fiber scheduler calls to go through

cards.summary: Feature request to add serialization context support for codecs and converters in the Ruby SDK, aligned with cross-SDK effort to standardize this capability including Nexus support.
cards.userImpact: Users will be able to pass context information to custom codecs and converters, enabling more sophisticated serialization strategies.
cards.proposedFix: Implement serialization context support as specified in the cross-SDK features issue #434, including Nexus support per issue #678.
cards.keyQuote: Make sure to include nexus per https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/678

cards.summary: Add support for the new Worker Versioning API in the Ruby SDK through workflow annotations. This involves implementing design specifications documented in a cross-SDK design document, with Go SDK as the reference implementation.
cards.userImpact: Users can adopt the new Worker Versioning API in Ruby, enabling safe deployment strategies and maintaining compatibility across workflow versions.
cards.proposedFix: Implement workflow annotations following the cross-SDK design specification referenced in the feature document, aligned with Go SDK implementation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support the new Worker Versioning API with appropriate annotations for the Ruby SDK.
cards.keyQuote: We need to add annotations to workflows to support the new versioning APIs. Refer to temporalio/features#548 for the Go equivalents.

cards.summary: Feature request to add saga pattern implementation to the Ruby SDK, similar to other Temporal SDKs. The maintainers declined, explaining that sagas are a pattern rather than a utility, and different use cases require different approaches.
cards.userImpact: Users can implement saga patterns directly in their workflows using standard Temporal APIs rather than relying on a built-in utility.
cards.rootCause: Saga is a pattern rather than a universal utility - different users need different compensation strategies (concurrent vs sequential, different error handling approaches).
cards.proposedFix: Implement saga pattern manually in workflow code using activity sequencing and exception handling, as shown in the maintainer's example.
cards.workaround: Use manual compensation activity sequencing with try-rescue blocks, as demonstrated in the maintainer's code example.
cards.resolutionDetails: Not planned as a built-in utility because the pattern is already supported through standard SDK capabilities. Pattern will instead be demonstrated in samples.
cards.keyQuote: saga is a pattern more than a utility...different people need different approaches (e.g. some want compensations concurrently, some want to collect compensation errors in different ways)

cards.summary: Add a nightly smoke benchmark test for the Ruby SDK to ensure high performance remains stable, similar to existing benchmarks in the Python and .NET SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Ensures the Ruby SDK maintains performance standards through automated nightly testing.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a nightly benchmark workflow similar to Python and .NET SDK workflows
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented and completed
cards.keyQuote: This is mostly a sanity check that high-performing Ruby works as expected.

cards.summary: Implement Nexus support in the Temporal Ruby SDK following the feature specification defined in the cross-repository Nexus initiative.
cards.userImpact: Ruby SDK users will be able to use Nexus for service-to-service workflow communication once this implementation is complete.
cards.proposedFix: Implement Nexus support in the Ruby SDK aligned with the specification in temporalio/features#609
cards.keyQuote: Alongside Nexus Ruby SDK, need Temporal-specific implementation in this SDK.

cards.summary: User requests a point release of the Ruby SDK with relaxed protobuf version constraints that were merged weeks ago but not yet published to RubyGems. The published version is missing this fix, forcing users to build from source.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot adopt the latest Ruby SDK on RubyGems due to strict protobuf version constraints, requiring workarounds like source builds.
cards.rootCause: Merged protobuf version relaxation has not been released to RubyGems; pending features (OTel, metric buffer) delayed the point release.
cards.proposedFix: Cut a new point release with the protobuf version relaxation and any pending features (OTel support, metric buffer).
cards.workaround: Build Ruby SDK from source to get the relaxed protobuf constraints.
cards.resolutionDetails: Point release was eventually published with the protobuf version relaxation and additional features (OTel, metric buffer).
cards.keyQuote: I can't switch to this because the version you've published to RubyGems doesn't have the relaxing on the protobuf version that you merged a few weeks ago.

cards.summary: Add support for custom metric bucket sizes in the Ruby SDK by exposing histogram bucket overrides that were made available in sdk-core.
cards.userImpact: Users can customize histogram bucket sizes for metrics collection to better suit their monitoring requirements.
cards.proposedFix: Expose histogram bucket overrides from sdk-core (as implemented in sdk-core PR #844) in the Ruby SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and the issue was closed.
cards.keyQuote: Need to expose histogram bucket overrides made available in https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/844.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose root workflow execution in the Ruby SDK, pending implementation of core SDK functionality and features specification.
cards.userImpact: Users need access to root workflow execution information for advanced workflow patterns and debugging.
cards.proposedFix: Implement root workflow execution exposure as specified in features/605 and sdk-core/881
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented after dependencies were resolved in core SDK and features specification
cards.keyQuote: Expose root workflow execution

cards.summary: Add documentation and validation to disallow keyword arguments in activities, workflows, signals, queries, and updates, ensuring consistency with Temporal's positional-only parameter model across all SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users may attempt to use keyword arguments in workflows/activities not realizing they are unsupported, leading to runtime failures or confusion.
cards.rootCause: Temporal only supports positional parameters in its serialized form, and keyword arguments create ambiguity in parameter arity across different SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Add validation at workflow/activity/signal/query/update definition time with clear error messages, and document this restriction prominently in README.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed indicating the feature request was addressed with documentation and validation rules implemented.
cards.keyQuote: All Temporal SDKs only support positional parameters, and all Temporal SDKs strongly encourage a single parameter that is an object/dict that can have fields added.

cards.summary: Request to implement custom slot suppliers in the Ruby SDK, similar to the existing Python implementation. This feature would allow users to provide custom logic for managing worker slot allocation.
cards.userImpact: Users can customize slot supplier behavior to implement specialized resource allocation strategies for their workers.
cards.proposedFix: Implement custom slot suppliers following the pattern established in the Python SDK (PR #690)
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented with comprehensive tests to verify slot info fields
cards.keyQuote: Support custom slot suppliers, e.g. like Python did

cards.summary: Feature request to ensure built-in query responses in the Ruby SDK use "RawValue" format, aligning with the cross-SDK features specification.
cards.userImpact: Users relying on built-in query responses will get consistent RawValue formatting across all Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement RawValue format for built-in query responses as specified in temporalio/features#604
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed after implementation of RawValue format for built-in queries
cards.keyQuote: Make sure built-in queries return a raw value

cards.summary: Add a test to verify that workflows using randomness produce different values after reset-point resets. The test should run a workflow with random inputs to activities, reset at a midpoint, and confirm that pre-reset values remain the same while post-reset values differ.
cards.userImpact: Users need test coverage to ensure workflow resets properly update randomness seeds and produce different results after reset points.
cards.proposedFix: Create a test workflow that executes activities with random-generated inputs, record the history, reset the workflow between two activities, re-execute, and assert that pre-reset values match but post-reset values differ.
cards.keyQuote: Add a test that will confirm post-reset-point workflows have a different update seed.

cards.summary: Add support for building the Ruby SDK from source during gem installation. Currently the source gem doesn't work, but the SDK could include necessary sdk-core components to enable building on `gem install --platform ruby` for users in obscure environments where pre-built gems aren't available.
cards.userImpact: Users in environments without pre-built gem support can now build and install the SDK from source if Rust is available.
cards.proposedFix: Include all necessary sdk-core components in the gem and add a smoke test that validates `gem install --platform ruby` can build successfully when Rust is available.
cards.keyQuote: we very well could include all the sdk-core stuff needed to build the entire SDK on gem install

cards.summary: Add support for user metadata on workflows, activities, and timers in the Ruby SDK. This includes accepting optional static summary and details parameters when starting workflows, creating activities and timers, and implementing the __temporal_workflow_metadata query handler.
cards.userImpact: Users can now attach descriptive metadata to workflows, activities, and timers to improve visibility and debugging of their temporal applications.
cards.proposedFix: Implement metadata parameters across workflow creation APIs, activity/timer creation, and add __temporal_workflow_metadata query handler based on Go SDK reference implementation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to match the Temporal features specification for user metadata support across all workflow creation patterns and activity/timer creation.
cards.keyQuote: Accept optional 'static summary' and 'static details' on all ways to start a workflow and populate user metadata with them

cards.summary: Request to build and distribute musl-compatible gem for Ruby SDK to support Alpine Linux and other musl-based distributions.
cards.userImpact: Users running on musl-based systems (Alpine Linux, etc.) cannot easily use pre-built gems and must compile from source.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed, likely implemented as part of gem packaging improvements
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/594

cards.userImpact: Users will have a more reliable and consistent documentation experience with a dedicated, well-maintained docs site integrated with other Temporal SDK documentation.
cards.rootCause: rubydoc.info is experiencing issues and not ideal for hosting canonical documentation
cards.proposedFix: Publish yard docs to ruby.temporal.io and update README to mark it as the canonical documentation location
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented hosting of Ruby SDK documentation at ruby.temporal.io with updated README to reflect canonical location
cards.keyQuote: publish yard docs to ruby.temporal.io as we do with dotnet.temporal.io, python.temporal.io, and typescript.temporal.io

cards.summary: Feature request to add support for attaching priority to workflows and activities in the Ruby SDK, similar to capabilities being implemented across Temporal SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently assign priority levels to workflows and activities in the Ruby SDK, limiting task scheduling flexibility.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented to support priority annotations for workflows and activities
cards.keyQuote: Add support for attaching priority to workflows/activities

cards.summary: Add explicit memoization support to the patched() API by introducing a `memoized` argument and delegating handling to Core for improved workflow behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users will have explicit memoization control through the patched() API, improving workflow consistency and flexibility.
cards.proposedFix: Add a `memoized` argument to the `patched` and `deprecatePatch` APIs and delegate handling logic to Core.
cards.keyQuote: Add a `memoized` argument to the `patched` and `deprecatePatch` APIs. Delegate handling of the `patched` logic to Core.

cards.summary: Feature request to add Ruby version requirement (>= 3.2.0) back to the gemspec now that rake-compiler-dock dependency issue is resolved.
cards.userImpact: Ensures users install the SDK on compatible Ruby versions, preventing runtime errors from version mismatches.
cards.proposedFix: Add required_ruby_version >= 3.2.0 to gemspec after rake-compiler-dock issue #145 is complete and released
cards.resolutionDetails: Likely implemented after rake-compiler-dock dependency was resolved
cards.keyQuote: With rake-compiler-dock/issues/145 complete and released, can put this limitation into the gemspec

cards.summary: Allow setting search attributes in dev server startup options for the Ruby SDK, translating them to --search-attribute CLI calls to align with recent CLI improvements.
cards.userImpact: Users can now configure search attributes directly in dev server startup options instead of managing them separately through CLI calls.
cards.proposedFix: Add support for accepting search attributes in dev server startup options that translate to --search-attribute CLI parameters.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to accept search attributes in dev server startup options.
cards.keyQuote: users should be allowed to set search attributes in dev server option that translate to `--search-attribute` calls

cards.summary: Feature request to allow customization of the development server UI port in the Ruby SDK, with reference to a cross-SDK features discussion.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot customize the port where the development server UI runs, limiting flexibility in local development environments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the feature request was addressed or resolved
cards.keyQuote: Allow customization of dev server UI port

cards.summary: Contributor requests a contributing guide for the Ruby SDK to understand how to build and contribute to the project. The maintainer indicates that development instructions exist in the README but suggests joining Slack for further guidance and points to the samples-ruby repository for contribution opportunities.
cards.userImpact: New contributors cannot easily understand how to set up and contribute to the Ruby SDK without external guidance.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose the ability to configure OTel metrics to use HTTP instead of the default gRPC protocol in the Ruby SDK. This aligns with a similar enhancement being considered for the Core library.
cards.userImpact: Users will have the option to export OTel metrics over HTTP instead of being limited to gRPC, providing more flexibility in observability setup.
cards.proposedFix: Add a simple boolean configuration option (default false) to enable HTTP protocol for OTel metrics.
cards.keyQuote: Expose ability to have Core OTel metrics use HTTP instead of default gRPC protocol.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement special behavior for Temporal built-in prefixes in the Ruby SDK, aligning with cross-SDK standards defined in the features repository.
cards.userImpact: Users will have consistent handling of built-in prefixes across all Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement special behavior for Temporal built-in prefixes as defined in temporalio/features#576
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented to align Ruby SDK with cross-SDK standards

cards.summary: Remove Go dependency from Ruby SDK's test pipeline. The Ruby SDK can now write the 'kitchen sink' workflow entirely in Ruby, eliminating the need for Go.
cards.userImpact: Simplifies the Ruby SDK build and test process by removing an external language dependency.
cards.proposedFix: Replace Go-based kitchen sink workflow with pure Ruby implementation
cards.keyQuote: Go is currently needed for the "kitchen sink" workflow, but we now have the ability to write that workflow in pure Ruby

cards.summary: Improve deadlock detection by interrupting deadlocked workflows post-eviction and providing the deadlocked thread's stack trace instead of the raise point stack trace.
cards.userImpact: Users will get better diagnostics when workflows deadlock, making it easier to debug and resolve deadlock issues.
cards.proposedFix: Interrupt the workflow if evicted post-deadlock and include the deadlocked thread's stack trace in the deadlock error.
cards.keyQuote: Try to interrupt the workflow if it is evicted post-deadlock and try to put the stack trace of the deadlocked thread as the deadlock error's stack trace.

cards.summary: Ensure the signal buffer is properly drained when a dynamic signal is added to a workflow. This addresses a TODO item from issue #183 related to signal handling.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience signal processing issues when dynamically adding signals to workflows if the buffer is not properly managed.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved as part of workflow improvements in issue #183
cards.keyQuote: Ensure signal buffer properly drained when dynamic signal added. There is a TODO in #183 for this.

cards.summary: Ruby SDK needs full OpenTelemetry tracing support to match capabilities available in other Temporal SDKs. This is a feature request to implement comprehensive OTel integration for distributed tracing.
cards.userImpact: Ruby SDK users cannot use OpenTelemetry for distributed tracing and observability like users of other Temporal SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Need full OTel tracing like other SDKs

cards.summary: Add three new client methods for signal-with-start and update-with-start workflows in Ruby SDK, aligning with the design pattern used in Python and .NET SDKs. This includes signal_with_start_workflow, start_update_with_start_workflow, and execute_update_with_start_workflow methods.
cards.userImpact: Users can now signal or update workflows at the time of starting them, providing feature parity with Python and .NET SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement three new methods on the client: signal_with_start_workflow, start_update_with_start_workflow, and execute_update_with_start_workflow, all accepting WithStartWorkflowOperation parameter.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to achieve API parity with Python and .NET SDKs for signal-with-start and update-with-start operations.
cards.keyQuote: We need the following methods on client: signal_with_start_workflow, start_update_with_start_workflow, execute_update_with_start_workflow

cards.summary: Request to implement a workflow replayer for the Ruby SDK with capabilities to stream histories, similar to existing implementations in Python and .NET SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users can test and debug workflows by replaying them with recorded histories, improving workflow reliability and troubleshooting capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Implement workflow replayer with history streaming capabilities, following patterns from Python and .NET SDK implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented in the Ruby SDK with workflow replayer and history streaming capabilities.
cards.keyQuote: Implement workflow replayer, including capabilities commonly seen in Python and .NET to stream histories

cards.summary: Request to expose a replay-safe metric meter from Ruby workflows, similar to Python and .NET SDKs, to allow recording metrics inside workflow code.
cards.userImpact: Ruby developers cannot record metrics from within workflows, limiting observability compared to other Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Expose replay-safe metric_meter similar to Python and .NET implementations
cards.resolutionDetails: Consolidated into #183 for broader workflow support implementation
cards.keyQuote: expose replay-safe `Temporalio::Workflow.metric_meter` for recording metrics inside workflows

cards.summary: Feature request to warn Ruby developers when workflow futures that have failed are never awaited, similar to existing Java SDK behavior. Could also warn on any unawaited futures regardless of failure status.
cards.userImpact: Developers will be alerted to potential bugs where failed workflow futures are silently ignored, preventing hard-to-debug issues.
cards.proposedFix: Implement warning on workflow completion when unawaited futures with failures are detected, following the Java SDK pattern already established.
cards.keyQuote: In Java workflows today, if a future that fails is never waited on, we warn on workflow completion. We should do the same in Ruby.

cards.summary: Evaluate and potentially implement Ractor-based sandboxing for Ruby SDK workflows. The main blocker is Google::Protobuf incompatibility with Ractors, which would require implementing a custom Protobuf solution.
cards.userImpact: Users could benefit from better workflow state isolation through Ractor-based sandboxing, but the feature is blocked by ecosystem limitations.
cards.rootCause: Google::Protobuf library does not support Ractors, and ecosystem support is still experimental
cards.proposedFix: Implement a custom Protobuf solution using method_missing approach (similar to Ruby extension implementation)
cards.resolutionDetails: Decision made to defer Ractor-based workflows due to Google::Protobuf incompatibility and experimental status. Will revisit when ecosystem support improves.
cards.keyQuote: It has been decided that while there are a lot of state-isolation benefits to Ractor-based workflows, since `Google::Protobuf` doesn't support them and since they are experimental, it is not worth the effort to require them today.

cards.summary: Windows CI tests are segfaulting during execution. Backtraces indicate the issue occurs within the Rust bridge's parking_lot mutex locking mechanism, which appears to be calling Ruby's rb_w32_Sleep from a non-Ruby thread, causing NULL pointer dereference.

cards.summary: Fiber-based workers hang in Ruby 3.1/3.2 when Queue.push is called from a separate thread, but work correctly in Ruby 3.3+. The issue appears related to changes in Ruby's M:N scheduling model, preventing fibers waiting on queue.pop() from being woken up by pushes from other threads.
cards.userImpact: Ruby 3.1/3.2 users cannot use fiber-based workers, limiting concurrency improvements to Ruby 3.3+ only.
cards.rootCause: Likely related to M:N scheduling changes introduced in Ruby 3.3. Queue.push from a separate thread does not reliably wake up a fiber waiting on queue.pop in Ruby < 3.3, though the exact mechanism is not fully understood.
cards.proposedFix: Consider reworking callback logic to use `captured_fiber_scheduler.fiber { queue.push }` instead of pushing from another thread, or investigate alternative methods to wake fibers from other threads.
cards.workaround: Restrict fiber-based workers to Ruby 3.3+ only; use thread-based workers for earlier Ruby versions.
cards.keyQuote: in some cases when we have one Ruby thread that pushes to a queue, a fiber that is waiting on queue pop is not woken up

cards.summary: A denial-of-service vulnerability (CVE-2022-3171) was identified in google-protobuf 3.21.6, a transitive dependency of grpc, affecting the Ruby SDK. The issue causes long garbage collection pauses when parsing certain binary data formats.

cards.rootCause: Parsing procedure for binary and text format data in protobuf causes objects to be converted back-and-forth between mutable and immutable forms, resulting in long garbage collection pauses.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade google-protobuf to version 3.21.7 or later (3.20.3, 3.19.6 also available depending on version requirements).
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or is no longer part of the Mend inventory, indicating the dependency has been removed or upgraded.
cards.keyQuote: Input streams containing multiple instances of non-repeated embedded messages with repeated or unknown fields cause objects to be converted back-n-forth between mutable and immutable forms, resulting in potentially long garbage collection pauses.
